page.title: Nominal Phrase - Article & Demonstrative: Case
page.introduction: Some languages mark the case of the nominal phrase by the form of the article and/or demonstrative.

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language have different forms for articles and/or demonstratives based on case?

form.instruction:
Since your language has a nominative-accusative case system, in the lexicon:
Mark the articles and demonstratives that go with subjects with the feature nominative and those that go with direct objects with the feature accusative.
If you have a set for possessors, add the feature genitive to those entries.
If a particular article or demonstrative can show up in any position, do not add any feature.
If a particular article or demonstrative can occur as a subject or as a possessor but not as the object of a verb or pre/post-position, add the feature nominative.or.genitive.
If a particular article or demonstrative can occur as a subject or as an object but not as a possessor, add the feature nominative.or.accusative.
If a particular article or demonstrative may occur as an object or as a possessor, but not as a subject, add the feature accusative.or.genitive.

Since your language has an ergative-absolutive case system, in the lexicon:
Mark the articles and demonstratives that go with subjects of transitive verbs with the feature ergative and those that go with direct objects and subjects of intransitive verbs with the feature absolutive.
If you have a distinct set for possessors, add the feature genitive to those entries, but if either the ergative or absolutive set is used for possessors as well, do not add any additional feature.
If a particular article or demonstrative can show up in any position, do not add any feature.

Since your language has a split ergativity case system, in the lexicon:
Mark the articles and demonstratives that occur with nominative nouns with the feature nominative and those that occur with accusative nouns with the feature accusative.
Mark the articles and demonstratives that occur with ergative nouns with the feature ergative and those that occurwith absolutive nouns with the feature absolutive.
If you have a distinct set for possessors, add the feature genitive to those entries.
If a particular article or demonstrative can show up in any position, do not add any feature.
